div.p: The original transcription is not available.

When it comes to the content of the legal status of Jews in Romania, I would like to note, firstly, that after the abolition of the old anti-Jewish laws in year 1919 there was no legal difference between a Jew and a non-Jew […]. Until recently, if a Jew had a Romanian nationality, facing the law he had the same rights as any other Romanian. It is crucial to note this fact, since it explains all the basis of this law. In general, it can be said that although everything depends on how the individual points of this law are going to be carried out in real life, right now it seems that it ended up quite benevolent for the Jews. This relative benevolence, however, does not mean that there was not enough will and determination at the relevant places to proceed more radically, rather I have

a feeling that it’s the missing resources, since the Jews play a very important role in the economic life of Romania. If they were suddenly excluded from all of the activities, it could have unpleasant results on all of the economic life.

So it seems that for these reasons the Jews had to be divided into 3 categories and the second category, especially all the Jewish frontline soldiers, are keeping almost all the rights, with some exceptions existing. With the new status, the first and the third category have, however, fairly limited options when it comes to some employments although they are not “expressis verbis” prohibited from doing business. Nevertheless, a Jew from these categories cannot be a member of any executive board anymore.

A general ban is placed on all the categories when it comes to ownership of rural land. This is nothing new for the Romanian circumstances, since a similar ban was formally valid in the old kingdom area up until 1919, if I am not being mistaken, when it was removed by the liberal regime.

I have to repeat myself by saying that at first glance the law seems to be quite benevolent for the local Jews and the information I am getting from the Romanian Christian bankers is that a weight was put off their hearts. The business in the banks has almost completely stopped due to the Jews fearing the upcoming law and now it is expected that the economic and financial life will come alive again, since the economic crisis is gone for now. It was a similar economic crisis

to the one which forced the government of Goga – Cuza to capitulat. Their strong nationalist and anti-Jewish program caused Jews to freak out and to stop trading, which hurt all of the Romania. The legal status of the Jews in Romania is, thus, much less brutal than the one in Germany, for example, and it could be compared “mutatis mutandis” to the Jewish laws in Hungary.

However, it should not be forgotten that it is only the first of the legal steps and is being less severe out of caution. This step can be followed by others, if the situation asks for it, which could touch the lives of Jews much more and with severe impact, since the nationalists are most probably not going to be very happy about this law and are expected to ask for further steps in time.

To the topic of the law against the mixed marriages I would like to note, that this law protecting the Romanian race is not of any major practical relevance, since based on my information, the mixed marriages have never threatened the Romanian race, although there were many of them, and [...] the number of the mixed marriages has almost declined to almost zero percent during the past months.
Made in 6 copies, 4 of them for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 1 copy for the army attaché and 1 copy to be stored within the records.
